images.copyright: Traditional fishing cabins, Svolvaer, Lofoten Islands, Norway (© Roberto Moiola/Sysaworld/Getty Images)
images.title: Life in a hut-shell
images.caption: Svolvaer, Lofoten Islands, Norway
images.desc: Housed in the Arctic Circle, Norway's Lofoten Islands are a crossroads of traditional life and modern industry. One of two towns in Lofoten, Svolvaer boasts a long history as a fishing village. Before it became a town of its own, it was part of the town of Vågan, where people lived for over 1,000 years. Beyond fishing, it also serves as a sanctuary for travellers looking for a peaceful getaway, with as many as 200,000 visitors in a single year. The traditional houses—called rorbu—are built on poles over water, and add a distinctive layer of charm to the town. These cabins were once made for travelling fishermen and have now been refurbished to meet contemporary tastes.

og.title: Svolvaer, Lofoten Islands, Norway

images.title: Paint your world red
images.caption: Red poinsettia
images.desc: During the holiday season, poinsettias are often seen adorning homes and festive displays, serving as symbols of goodwill and community spirit. Named after the American ambassador Joel Poinsett, who introduced it to North America in the 19th century, the poinsettia's association with Christmas has made it a cherished symbol of warmth and celebration. Poinsettias can be found in nature from Mexico to Guatemala, and the ancestors of the modern, commercially available version have been traced to the Mexican state of Guerrero. The crimson-leaved plant was used by the Aztecs as a red dye and as a fever-reducing medicine.

images.copyright: Winter in Huangshan Mountains, China (© Hung Chung Chih/Shutterstock)
images.title: Care for a peak?
images.caption: Huangshan Mountains, China
images.desc: These highlands are the Huanghan Mountains—also called the Yellow Mountains—of China's Anhui province. In 1990, these peaks were granted the prestigious title of a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The iconic granite peaks, covered with mist in winters, create a surreal atmosphere that has captivated artists and poets for centuries. Rising majestically to a height of 965 metres, the Huangshan Mountains are composed of granite that formed 140 million years ago during the late Jurassic period. Visitors come here to experience the breathtaking rock formations, pine trees, ethereal seas of clouds, hot springs and captivating winter landscapes. So, let's climb high, dream big and protect our mountains!

images.copyright: Last rays of sun on a group of dunes, Sahara, Algeria (© AWL Images/DanitaDelimont.com)
images.title: Each day a different dune
images.caption: Sand dunes in the Sahara, Algeria
images.desc: The Sahara is a vast expanse of desert in North Africa that spans over 7.7 million square kilometres. The wilderness' vast sand dunes, rocky plateaus and occasional oases create a landscape like no other. Although it is the largest hot desert in the world, the Sahara is home to a variety of unique life, including drought-resistant plants like acacia and palm trees, and hardy animals such as camels and fennec foxes. One of the Sahara's intriguing features is its constantly shifting sand dunes, pictured in today's image, some of which can reach heights of over 152 metres. The desert also holds historical significance; ancient rock art and fossils have been discovered, providing insights into early human civilisations and prehistoric creatures. Sandstorms are common, shaping the ever-changing scenery and adding to the mystique of this natural wonder.

images.copyright: India gate war memorial designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens in New Delhi, India. (© Amit kg/Shutterstock)
images.title: A majestic frame for an eternal flame
images.caption: India gate, New Delhi, India
images.desc: India Gate, a grand war memorial in New Delhi designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens, commemorates the Indian soldiers who lost their lives during World War I. It features the names of the more than 13,500 soldiers who fell on the Northwestern Frontier in 1919. Under the gate is the eternal flame, known as the Amar Jawan Jyoti, which honours the unknown soldiers of the 1971 Indo-Pakistan War. The India Gate was unveiled in 1931 by the Duke of Connaught. The 42-metre-high arch, reminiscent of the Parisian Arc de Triomphe, stands at the end of the Rajpath, connecting it with the Rashtrapati Bhavan. The memorial has become a symbol of national unity and a site for various commemorations, including Republic Day parades.
images.bsTitle: A majestic frame for an eternal flame

images.copyright: La Rocque Harbour, St. Clement, Island of Jersey (© Reinhard Schmid/Huber/eStock Photo)
images.title: Not that Jersey Shore
images.caption: La Rocque Harbour, Island of Jersey
images.desc: Just off the coast of Normandy, France lies Jersey, a British island with a Norse name. Found on the southeastern shore of the island is La Rocque Harbour, home to a white, sandy beach and an elevated walkway that stretches out into the water. The shoreline's granite and plutonic rocks, which originated more than 420 million years ago, showcase a variety of colours and textures. Visible from the harbour are the round, stubby Icho Tower and the taller Seymour Tower, built in the 18th and 19th centuries respectively as coastal defence structures. Both structures are over 550 metres away from the shore and can be reached on foot with a sturdy pair of shoes, but only on the days of the year when the tide is lowest.

images.copyright: A foggy morning at Verdon Gorge in the Alpes-de-Haute-Provence of France (© Hemis/Alamy)
images.title: Is this a river of clouds?
images.caption: Verdon Gorge, France
images.desc: Stretching nearly 100 kilometres, the Verdon Gorge is Europe's largest canyon, with majestic cliffs climbing up to 750 metres in height. The emerald hue of the Verdon River's waters, hidden far below this blanket of clouds, lends its name to this spectacular natural site, shaped by millions of years of erosion. Visitors or residents of Alpes-de-Haute-Provence Hiking in the southeast of France can visit the canyon for rock climbing, kayaking, paragliding—the adventure options are endless. If you find yourself in Marseille or Nice, a day trip may be in order.
images.bsTitle: Is this a river of clouds?

images.copyright: Beach with bungalow and coconut palm trees at Palolem in Goa, India. (© Pikoso.kz/Shutterstock)
images.title: A sand-sational escapade
images.caption: Palolem beach, Goa, India
images.desc: The Indian state of Goa is renowned for its pristine coastline and serene waters. Among its many gems, Palolem Beach is a mile-long crescent-shaped beach lined with swaying palm trees and colourful houses. Busiest between November and March, the mix of foreign tourists and local fishermen in the adjacent village creates a unique blend of cultures. Palolem is also famous for the diverse activities it offers, including yoga sessions, silent discos and exciting dolphin-spotting excursions. This coastal paradise is the perfect spot for a seaside retreat, offering a range of experiences to cater to every visitor's preferences.
